title: Mum's life is ruined by mystery illness which means she can no longer control her body
text:
News Mum's life is ruined by mystery illness which means she can no longer control her body Babs is understood to be one of only four people who suffer with iron accumulation on the brain in the UK Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Mother struggles with daily life due to rare condition Share this video Get daily   
The family of a young mum whose life has been ruined by mystery neurological illness have launched a desperate search for answers. 
Barbara Mason, 32, suffers with a neurological disorder known as iron accumulation on the brain and is gradually losing control of her ability to move. 
The mum-of-one, known as Babs, first started showing symptoms of her illness two and half years ago - but she still has not been given an official diagnosis from doctors. 
Babs is understood to be one of only four people who suffer with iron accumulation on the brain in the UK, meaning medics know very little about her condition. Read More Family of 5-year-old who died after being crippled by arthritis say it took 20 hospital visits to diagnose him 
Her illness has started to deteriorate dramatically in recent months - prompting her parents to appeal to other people with the illness or neurological experts who may be able to help. 
Doctors have prescribed medication usually given to people with Parkinson’s Disease, yet her symptoms are still getting worse. 
Babs, from Irlam, is now at a stage where she struggles to control the movement of her arms and legs. 
Simple tasks such as getting dressed can take her up to an hour and she now struggles to write her own name. It has also had devastating effect on her confidence. 
Her physical deterioration means she has to rely on parents, Barbara and Pete Mason, to help look after her little boy Lawrence, aged 18 months, who was born before Babs’ symptoms became severe. Barbara Mason and Daughter Barbara (Photo: Vincent Cole) 
At the moment they both support Babs and Lawrence around full time jobs. 
Her mother Barbara, 55, said: “We are at our wits end with what’s happened. 
“We still have never been given a proper diagnosis. We’re now at stage where Babs is having one appointment with the consultant every six months. Read More Drunk bus passenger jailed over 'vile and disgusting' racist abuse shared on Facebook 
“We have no complaints with Salford Royal - they have done everything they can. It’s just that they don’t have any other patients with the same illness. 
“It’s heartbreaking for a parent to see their daughter like this. Babs has no life any more. Barbara Mason and Daughter Barbara (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
“We’re trying to do everything we can so she can maintain as much independence and dignity as possible. 
“But it’s very difficult. Babs can fall more than 12 times a day on a bad day. 
“Her walking is very stiff now and sometimes her legs just give way. It’s scary for us in case something bad happens to her while we’re out. 
“We’re at a stage where we feel like no one is fighting for her. 
“We’re hoping by publicising her illness someone somewhere might be able to give us some advice on treatment or medication. 
“We don’t know what the future holds. We are just desperate to help improve our daughter’s quality of life in any way.” Like us on Facebook
